comments:
This is happening in M8.

After I run Ant several times, via selecting the build.xml and right clicking
Run Ant... or via the Run External.., my environment goes into a state where:

* I can't run Ant again. The dialog box does nothing when I hit Run on the
dialog box.
* I cannot exit properly. The exit dialog comes up, I hit OK, but nothing seems
to happen. I hit Exit again, and the UI goes away.
* The UI is gone, but Eclipse is still running. When I try to start again,
Eclipse compains that the workspace is in use, and I have to kill the process.
* Restart Eclipse and get "Unable to read workbench state. Workbench UI layout
will be reset"
* The workbench is reset, of course. Sometimes, my projects have been blown away
and I have to add them again.


Here is my log:

The first problem comes from trying to run an Ant build. The second comes from
trying to exit.

Are you running Ant in the same or separate VM (see the JRE tab for your Ant 
launch configuration)? I am suspious that you are running out of memory.

It is in a separate VM. I am starting M8 with  -vmargs -Xmx256M, and it appears
to be a process of 150M in the Task Manager.

That would appear to rule out an out of memory.

So to re-iterate:
You run the Ant build several times successfully.
Then suddenly it fails and appears to "hang" the workspace

You make no changes to the Ant runtime classpath etc and this is repeatable on 
the same build file?

Can you provide the buildfile and all relevant settings for reproduction of 
the problem?

From the stack traces it would appear that XML transform factory 
com.icl.saxon.TransformerFactoryImpl has gone missing. I am not familiar with 
this implementation or where it came from but it is not from the Eclipse Ant 
integration. Without any more info I am going to mark this bug as invalid 
against Eclipse.

com.icl.saxon.TransformerFactoryImpl is part of Saxon. Is there something in
running Ant that does not clear up after itself properly?


Sherman
Can you provide a buildfile that exhibits the problem so I can investigate?

This is still happening in M9. I will try and get a small build file that
exhibits the behavior.

Sherman

With nothing more to go on I am marking this bug as invalid.
Please reopen if you can provide a reproduceable test case.

I see the same problem with 3.1 200410050800 and I was able to narrow it down to
ANT editor. The following build.xml is extraction of relevant parts of JBoss
build scripts

================
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<project default="test">
  <target name="test">
    <path id="buildmagic.task.classpath">
        <fileset dir="lib">
           <include name="*"/>
        </fileset>
    </path>
    <taskdef name="property" classname="org.jboss.tools.buildmagic.task.Property">
    	<classpath >
    		<fileset dir="lib" includes="buildmagic-tasks.jar"/>
    	</classpath>
    </taskdef>
    <property system="true"
        name="javax.xml.transform.TransformerFactory"
        value="com.icl.saxon.TransformerFactoryImpl"/>
  </target>
</project>
================

You will get TransformerFactoryConfigurationError if you open this build script
in ANT editor (make sure you have buildmagic-tasks.jar! I'll attach it in a
moment) and exit Eclipse after that. As you can see, JBoss build scripts
override <property> task with their own extended version which supports
additional "system" property. Apparently, ANT editor tries to evaluate this
extended property which pretty much kills Eclipse runtime. Note that everything
works fine if I rename JBoss'es property to something different from <property/>.

For your convenience, here is a link to the source of JBoss'es version of
property task

http://cvs.sourceforge.net/viewcvs.py/jboss/buildmagic/tasks/src/main/org/jboss/tools/buildmagic/task/Property.java?rev=1.3&view=auto

Hope this helps.

Created an attachment (id=15088)
buildmagic-tasks.jar
Thanks Igor for the information. Reopening to investigate.

The ant editor execute's property tasks to set the property in the project so 
that the full set of properties are available for code assist.

Igor and others, 
with the attached test case and the JBoss property file I have no problems on 
I200411240800.

The property is executed within the context of the Ant editor and the property 
is available via code assist. No crash etc.

Marking as worksforme. Please reopen if related further issues.

Spoke to soon, 
Setting system properties can and will cause trouble. 

The sample buildfile stomps on the javax.xml.transform.TransformerFactory 
system property. 
Most XML processing will then fail. 

Needs more thought...

Note that the Ant editor does not even need to be involved. 
If you run Ant in the same JRE as Eclipse you are affecting the system 
properties of Eclipse.
*** Bug 81767 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***

One idea would be to install a SecurityManager that would not allow the 
modification of System properties

This only handles the editor case...we really cannot disallow setting of all 
System properties for builds in the same JRE as Eclipse. Some cases would be 
valid.
And coming up with the correct list of properties to disallow modification 
would be pratically impossible.

Other ideas:
> You might try exploring how using System.getProperties() and 
> System.setProperties() behaves. I would think you could either:
> A) grab a copy of the system props before invoking Ant /custom tasks, 
> then restore it after Ant is finished, throwing away any changes that 
> Ant tasks made.
> or
> B) replace the System properties object with some kind of Decorator that 
> does not allow the Ant tasks to change system properties, or allows it 
> but automatically drops those changes upon completion.
> 
> I'm not sure how well this would work, since much of the core Java code 
> seems to cache values it gets from System properties. But it is probably 
> worth some experimenting to find out.
> 
> HTH,
> Eric

I have had some early success using a security manager that is thread based to 
disallow the setting of System properties for the thread associated with 
reconciling the AntEditor.

Changes to 
AntSecurityManager: thread based permission checking for setting System 
properties
AntModel to add/remove the security manager during buildfile resolution
AntDefiningTaskNode, AntImportNode, AntPropertyNode, AntTaskNode: catch and 
report the security exception

Changes as well:
AntModelMessages for nls'ing
AntEditorPreferenceConstants: constants for the security problems and 
initialization
AntEditorPreferencePage: present the security problem severity level to the 
user for configuration
AntPreferenceMessages.properties: nls'ing
Please verify Jared.
Verified.
